lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''A Kinder, Gentler Kennedy Runs for Governor'' (Postcard From the Campaign, Aug. 12) shows us the tightrope that women running for executive office must walk. But when women run for mayor, governor or president, voters say they fear that she won't be tough enough to handle the economy or war.

snippet: To the Editor:    To state, as Judith Shulevitz does in her review of Susan Faludi's ''Stiffed'' (Oct. 3), that ''you would never know from 'Stiffed' that American economic growth is the highest it's been in a quarter-century and unemployment the ...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: To state, as Judith Shulevitz does in her review of Susan Faludi's ''Stiffed'' (Oct. 3), that ''you would never know from 'Stiffed' that American economic growth is the highest it's been in a quarter-century and unemployment the lowest'' is to miss entirely the key feature of the postindustrial economy. Aggregate economic indicators tell us very little about the lives of working people today. In the global economy, national economic growth and high corporate profits are often built upon a lean and mean workplace with no job security and weakened benefits packages. Unemployment statistics tell us even less. Postindustrial economic fear is not driven by the availability of jobs so much as the nature of the jobs available. People fear that if they get laid off, their next job will not provide adequate wages or benefits.
abstract: Nancy Wiefek letter contends that Judith Shulevitz's October 3 review of Susan Faludi book Stiffed misses key feature of post-industrial economy, that it is based on lean and mean workplace with no job security and weakened benefits packages

headline.main: 'Stiffed'

abstract: FTC issues guidelines to force auto makers to tell whole truth about auto fuel econ; ad making fuel econ claims must cite EPA test results both for city and hwy driving in clear and conspicuous manner; fuel econ claims for autos available in more than 1 engine size, transmission type or fuel system must disclose those factors; ad citing non-EPA figures must state optional equipment carried that may affect fuel econ; ad must stress that claims are estimates and that actual mileage may differ depending on driving habits, condition of the car arid optional equipment; Bur of Consumer Protection Dir J Thomas Rosch says that EPA tests, despite shortcomings, are only common reference that can now be used for guidelines and that bur is unhappy with way advertisers have been using EPA numbers (M)

lead_paragraph: Unemployment among veterans of the Vietnam war era fell substantially in 1972, the Labor Department said today. The rate dropped from 8.1 per cent in December, 1971, to 5.5 per cent last month, which was lower than the rate for male nonveterans of the same age.
abstract: Labor Sec J D Hodgson informs Pres Nixon that unemployment among Vietnam veterans fell from 8.1% in Dec '71 to 5.5% in Dec '72, figure lower than that for male non-veterans of same age; says improvements came about as result of special efforts by Govt, business and labor to locate jobs and as result of fewer servicemen being released from armed forces; adds joblessness 'no longer constitutes problem' among group

snippet: Talking female entrepreneurship at "Davos for women."...
lead_paragraph: This week I travel to Deauville, France, to attend the sixth Women's Forum for the Economy and Society, an annual meeting that brings together influential women -- and men -- from around the world. Described as "Davos for Women," the forum was founded by French entrepreneur Aude de Thuin, who saw a need to give voice to the other half of the population after she failed to receive an invitation to the predominantly male gathering in the Swiss Alps. The 2010 forum will focus on change in politics, the economy, the environment, global health, and the steps necessary to enable progress in all by facilitating full participation by women.

Pounded into terrorized conformity by his employer (himself a victim of the process), he has since proved a helpless and easily identified target for shafting, dissection and dismemberment by social anthropologists, lay analysts, depth probers and journalists.

headline.main: Of Man And Mouse; THE DECLINE OF THE AMERICAN MALE. By the editors of Look. Illustrated by Robert Osborn. 66 pp. New York: Random House. $2.95.

snippet: For the first time, white men, the prototype of the American worker since the beginning of the nation, no longer make up the majority of the country's work force.    In 1983, white male workers fell to 49.8 percent of the work force, from 50 perce...
lead_paragraph: For the first time, white men, the prototype of the American worker since the beginning of the nation, no longer make up the majority of the country's work force. In 1983, white male workers fell to 49.8 percent of the work force, from 50 percent in 1982. For the first six months of 1984, the trend continued, and by June white male workers made up 49.3 percent of the work force. As recently as 1970, white men made up 55.6 percent of the work force. Thirty years ago, in 1954, they made up 62.5 percent.

headline.main: SHIFT IN COUNTRY'S WORK FORCE DROPS WHITE MEN FROM MAJORITY POSITION

snippet: The retail phase of the Presidential campaign just ended abruptly. After an unusually short pre-season run, the candidates now shift from personal politicking into industrial mode. In the next three weeks, two dozen states will conduct primaries o...
lead_paragraph: The retail phase of the Presidential campaign just ended abruptly. After an unusually short pre-season run, the candidates now shift from personal politicking into industrial mode. In the next three weeks, two dozen states will conduct primaries or caucuses; the candidates will need to magnify their messages with media and mailings. New Hampshire can provide some momentum; Gary Hart's 1984 victory there probably catapulted him to his success soon after in Florida. What New Hampshire surely provides is lessons for the spring campaign:

headline.main: Lessons From New Hampshire

snippet: Why are men so much more concerned about their bodies today than they were 50 years ago?    This was the question Harrison G. Pope Jr., a professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, and two colleagues asked themselves after noticing a sharp...
lead_paragraph: Why are men so much more concerned about their bodies today than they were 50 years ago? This was the question Harrison G. Pope Jr., a professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, and two colleagues asked themselves after noticing a sharp increase in male gym memberships, anabolic steroid use and especially body image disorders, including muscle dysmorphia (sometimes called bigorexia), an illness characterized by compulsive exercising and the sufferer's irrational conviction that he is weak and puny even though he may be bulging with muscle.
abstract: Article discusses perceived threat to masculinity and reasons for it; Lionel Tiger, anthropoligist at Rutgers University, contends birth control pill is responsible for men's decline in status; author Susan Faludi (Stiffed: The Betrayal of American Men) argues problem has less to do with feminism than with surviving in retail culture that values body image and sex appeal; says pressures men feel today are those women have been working to overcome for years; photo (M)

headline.main: In This Woman's World, What's a Guy to Do? Sweat!

snippet: IN late July, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began shutting down strip clubs, and over the next month, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 1,500 points. In September, a court ruling gave some clubs a partial reprieve, whereupon the market began to...
lead_paragraph: IN late July, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began shutting down strip clubs, and over the next month, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 1,500 points. In September, a court ruling gave some clubs a partial reprieve, whereupon the market began to recover. Last Wednesday, a strip club won another round in court, and the Dow surged 250 points the rest of the week. Mere coincidences? The Mayor apparently thinks so, since he is continuing his dangerous crusade. But the stripper-Dow connection is all too obvious to those versed in the scientific literature of endocrinology. The market plummeted in August -- and will plummet again if Mr. Giuliani prevails -- because of a testosterone drought.
abstract: John Tierney humorous column links ups and downs activity of Dow Jones Industrial Average to ups and downs of New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's attempts to shut down city's strip clubs; drawing (M)

headline.main: The Big City; Monkey Business: Strippers, Testosterone and the Dow

snippet: It might seem churlish to find fault with a best-in-a-generation economy. Unemployment and inflation rates are at record lows, and low-paid workers are, for the first time in decades, receiving wage increases that outpace price increases. But desp...
lead_paragraph: It might seem churlish to find fault with a best-in-a-generation economy. Unemployment and inflation rates are at record lows, and low-paid workers are, for the first time in decades, receiving wage increases that outpace price increases. But despite the benefits of a temporarily buoyant economy, deep-seated problems remain. Frank Levy, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, notes that the best time to tackle problems is when the economy is flush. He points to increasing inequality at a time of stagnating wages in his new book, ''The New Dollars and Dreams'' (Russell Sage Foundation, 1998). Borrowing a phrase from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Mr. Levy warns against ''defining deviancy down -- accepting economic outcomes as normal today that would have been seen as pathological 10 or 20 years ago.''
abstract: Deep-seated problems remain despite benefits of temporary buoyant economy; discussion of five profound problems facing American economy: income inequality, wealth inequality, sluggish productivity, education gap and tattered safety blanket; drawing (M)

headline.main: 5 Problems Tarnishing a Robust Economy

snippet: Robert M. Miller, a lawyer who advised bondholders of companies like Macy's and the Trump Taj Mahal during the last wave of corporate bankruptcies a decade ago, is back. After a six-year hiatus from full-time bankruptcy work, Mr. Miller has joined...
lead_paragraph: Robert M. Miller, a lawyer who advised bondholders of companies like Macy's and the Trump Taj Mahal during the last wave of corporate bankruptcies a decade ago, is back. After a six-year hiatus from full-time bankruptcy work, Mr. Miller has joined Financo, an advisory firm specializing in the retail industry, as head of its new restructuring practice. Mr. Miller said he figured his talents would be a good fit with Financo's specialty, because every economic downturn includes its share of failed retailers. ''There are always retailers who expand too fast, or take on too much debt,'' he said. ''It's a fickle area of the economy.'' He will also solicit clients in other industries.
abstract: Robert M Miller joins Financo Inc, specialists in restructuring failed retailers (S)

headline.main: Private Sector; He Just Couldn't Stay Away
